text_image_relationship.layout_style: Two columns of three narrative compartments defined by Gothic arcades; each row separated by a line of vernacular captions above and below; wide decorative border of interlocking red and blue geometric motifs frames the page; equal visual weight to each compartment in a strict grid organization.

text_content.language: Old French (with traces of Occitan vernacular)
text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata in brown-black ink; professional book-hand with regular letterforms, extensive use of common medieval abbreviations and ligatures, rubricated capitals marking scene captions

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold reserved for halos, throne backgrounds, and key divine figures; ultramarine for princely robes and architectural vaulting; vermillion alternating with blue in diapered throne patterns and border motifs; layered application with white highlights on drapery folds; overall palette well-preserved with minimal darkening of white lead areas.

features: strict grid of six equal compartments
kneeling figures consistently oriented toward enthroned or central figures
central vertical architectural pier divides columns
decorative diaper backgrounds on thrones repeat motif

decorative_elements: interlocking red-and-blue geometric border with gold bezants
diaper-patterned throne backgrounds in alternating red, blue, gold
Gothic micro-architectural arcades with clustered columns and cusped arches
rubricated captions above and below each row

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in brown ink with varying line weight for contours and internal drapery folds
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal parallel hatching in ink; areas of color modeled by layering pigment with white lead highlights at fold creases
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling; no attempt at linear perspective; depth indicated by overlapping elements and reduction of scale in background architecture

Architectural vaulting continues across the two compartments

Gilded halo around abbot echoed around child in following scenes
Architectural column aligns with middle-left arcade

scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Prefigures divine visitation in lower left

Leaf green of foliage matches next scene’s robes

scene_relationships.subject: Deathbed scene of the saint surrounded by apostles and angels
visual_connections: Group of figures under continuous arcade
Blue drapery of bedcover echoes upper scene robes
Angelic figures’ halos match all other halos
Gold highlights on wings and bedposts carry palette
Compositional focus shifts to central bed as in other thrones

visual_continuity: Diaper-patterned dais or throne beneath key figures
Consistent palette of red, blue, green, gold
Hierarchical scaling of divine figures larger than mortals

content_theme.scene_description: The lower right Dormition scene shows a recumbent female figure on a richly draped bier beneath a triple cusped arcade. Six seated apostles surround the bed, three to each side, all clad in flowing robes of ultramarine, vermillion, and leaf green, their gestures expressive—one lifts his hand in blessing, another clasps his hands in prayer. Two standing angels to the left, rendered with burnished gold halos and feathered wings highlighted in white, hold up a white pall above the bed. The bedcover is patterned in alternating red and blue with gold bezants; the feet rest on a low step edged in gold. Depth is suggested by overlapping figures and the alternating arch columns receding toward the background. The apostles’ robes display fine hatching at folds and white lead highlights. Their facial expressions are individualized, with grey-brown ink underdrawing visible at eyes and mouths. The architectural framing—a three-bay arcade on clustered columns with foliate capitals—unifies this compartment with the rest of the grid.

symbolic: Hermit figure with goats and donkey (middle right)
Parent figures kneeling in veneration (multiple scenes)

objects: Ornate gold-detailed throne with diaper pattern
architectural: Gothic triple cusped arcades on clustered columns
natural: Stylized tree with gold leaves (middle right)

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum (smooth flesh side), uniform parchment thickness; ruled in plummet with layout conforming to quaternion gatherings.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent; pigments retain vibrancy, minimal flaking of vermillion, slight cockling at folio edges, no modern restoration evident on image surface.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf on halos and diaper patterns
Visible underdrawing in brown ink under color layers
Regular brush-stroke texture in drapery pigment
Punchwork decoration in gold leaf creating dotted pattern

functional_analysis.primary_function: Private devotion (Book of Hours cycle of Marian and saintly episodes)
secondary_functions: Display of patron’s wealth and piety
Memory aid for recitation of devotional offices
Visual aid for preaching on saint’s virtues

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This folio, likely produced in a mid-14th-century Parisian workshop, exemplifies the integration of vernacular hagiography with the pictorial innovations emerging in courtly Book of Hours illumination. The strict grid of six narrative compartments, each beneath uniform Gothic arcades, reflects a systematic approach to devotion, guiding the viewer through discrete episodes in the saint’s life and the Virgin’s Mysteries. The burnished gold leaf and use of ultramarine signal both the theological centrality of Marian intercession and the patron’s resources. The workshop’s technical prowess is evident in the raised gesso work beneath the gold and the confident underdrawing visible at the margins of drapery folds. Iconographically, the sequence links Old and New Testament motifs—hermit-like purification in the wilderness preceding apparition scenes and culminating in the Dormition—underscoring the saint’s role as intercessor. Artistically, the page balances conventional hierarchical scaling with emerging individualization of facial types among the apostles, suggesting a collaborative atelier with multiple hands. Comparative parallels can be drawn to the Hours of Jeanne de Navarre (Bnf, Latin 15949), sharing similar diapered throne patterns and border geometries, yet here the narrative integration shows greater pictorial economy. The result is a devotional program that marries traditional iconographic schemas with refined, courtly aesthetic sensibilities.
